data.title: Add ability to disable several or all keymaps of specific package
data.body: It would be nice in a situation where I need to use another hotkeys for the package API, but default hotkeys of package will be still active and there is no way to disable it but leave active all other keymaps.

data.title: Ubuntu 14.04 , Atom 0.190.0 don't support chinese.
data.body: I install many versions, when I try the version more than 0.187.0 ,it can't display chinese normal. I have read former Issues, many people say I can't try to change the font-family , but it doesn't work.

data.title: Atom As Daemon
data.body:
Hi!

**Postive:**
I've been so happy with Atom, it replaced my IntelliJ/PHPStorm and other IDE's incl. Vim and Sublime Text as a general purpose editor and sometimes IDE for a wide array of languages. 

**Negative:**
Now here is my problem: The startup-time is frustrating.

Can't I run atom as a daemon during startup and attach it to the [daemon like emacs-client](http://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/EmacsAsDaemon)?

Hey, that's also a good business model for you @github :+1:

data.title: Replace Bootstrap CSS with hand-written CSS designed for Atom
data.body:
The bootstrap CSS is enormous. It is designed to solve a problem that Atom does not have. That is, a set of CSS rules to normalize presentation across all browsers that may be used for rendering, using whatever browser-specific hacks necessary to achieve that goal.

The project was also conceived before the advent of flexbox, which means that bootstrap has a ton of cruft to deal with pre-flexbox browsers. Such workarounds are verbose and make it difficult to understand what can be removed.

In sum, this puts Atom into a situation where:
- The CSS is much larger than what Atom needs.
- It requires much more work than should be necessary to understand why the current CSS works the way it does.
- Bootstrap is the source of truth, rather than something that is directly under Atom's control.

For example, take a look at the issue I recently filed against Bootstrap: https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/issues/16276. The recommended solution is to pile on another hack (i.e., use an even more specific CSS selector) rather than figure out why the existing CSS works the way it does and fix the underlying problem with the model. Presumably this is because trying to untangle why things work the way they do is too hard.

Atom should not be saddled with the baggage of layout engines of old and should be exploiting the fact that it only needs to support Blink (which supports flexbox), and write its own small, specific, and far more maintainable CSS.

data.title: ATOM_HOME environment variable should be used if available.
data.body:
If ATOM_HOME is set then `(HOME|USERPROFILE)\.atom` should not be used.  This is violated in the following locations:

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/build/tasks/clean-task.coffee#L17-L20
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/script/clean#L11-L28
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/script/cibuild#L8-L85
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/build/Gruntfile.coffee#L44-L101

This is tangentially related to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6345 in that USERPROFILE should not be used.  However, in these cases you can't override the incorrect current behavior with an environment variable.

data.title: Debian x86 Package
data.body: Please, a x86 deb package would be nice

data.title: Changes ATOM_HOME on Windows to be APPDATA.
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6345.

This doesn't address the migration issue where a user may be upgrading from a previous version of ATOM and have files currently stored in `~/.atom`.  How this is resolved is a much bigger design decision than I am qualified to make so I will leave it up to the Atom maintainers.

My 2 cents is that migration occurs on first-run after an upgrade.  It is unclear to me if Atom has mechanisms in place to make this easy or not.  Alternatively, every run of atom could check to see if there are files in the old location and if so, migrate them.

data.title: ATOM_HOME on Windows should follow Windows conventions, not Linux conventions.
data.body:
In the Linux world, the convention is to put user-specific application configuration in `~/.folder` or `~/.file`.  In the Windows world, this is not the case.  User-specific settings have a well defined place they should go which is `~/AppData/(Local|Roaming|LocalLow)`.

Details on exactly which of the three folders to use can be found here: http://windows.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-8/what-appdata-folder

Additional information about how to access the different paths can be found here (a bit old, but still valuable):
http://blogs.msdn.com/b/patricka/archive/2010/03/18/where-should-i-store-my-data-and-configuration-files-if-i-target-multiple-os-versions.aspx

Reasoning: `~/.(file|folder)` is not hidden on Windows and it is not the place an experienced Windows developer would look for user settings.  It also pollutes the user directory which is meant to be the place for user documents and files that they interact with directly (word document, photos, videos, downloads, etc.).

data.title: TopMenu support
data.body:
I want to use Atom with TopMenu plugin for mate-panel on Linux desktops, but to do this menu need to be shown with GTK or Qt (because TopMenu don't use dbus and grabs menubar via XEmbed) or Atom needs special plugin for exporting menu for TopMenu exclusively. So there is a question: have i any possibility to show Atom menubar as GTK menubar to allow TopMenu plugin grab it via XEmbed?

Some info about how TopMenu works here: https://git.javispedro.com/cgit/topmenu-gtk.git/about/

data.title: Fix doc on getting the home directory
data.body: `atom.fs` is undefined in the current Atom version. The function `getHomeDirectory()` seems to be now only available in the Atom `fs-plus` package.

data.title: Save and Save As buttons on Menu - Doesn't work
data.body:
Hi

I have downloaded Windows (8.1) version of Atom from the link provided on the home page.

After installation and adding some of the packages In the first run when I tried to save the file using menu "File/Save" as well as "File/Save As" did not work but CTRL+S worked.

Regards
Dev

data.title: Issues with Atom on Windows tablet
data.body:
Sometimes I want to use atom on my Windows tablet, and I've noticed two annoying issues.

Firstly, whenever you click anywhere on the editor, it opens the software keyboard. This would be fine, except that it does so even if you have a hardware/bluetooth keyboard attached. I'm not sure if Windows provides a way to tell if there is a physical keyboard attached, but if not, could you provide an option to not open the software keyboard ever? 

The other issue is with scrolling. With apps designed for touch screens, you can drag down from the top of the editor and it scrolls down. However this doesn't seem to work with atom, and you have to grab the very thin scrollbar on the side on order to scroll down. Would it be possible to allow drag-scrolling?

Thanks so much, I love the editor!

data.title: Links do not work in v189+
data.body: After upgrading to Atom 189, links no longer open a new tab in Chrome.  For example, clicking on any of the release notes links does nothing.  Upgrading to 190 didn't solve this issue.

data.title: Error: EEXIST on launch from shell as non-root
data.body:
OSX 10.10.3
Atom 0.190.0

When launching atom as a non-root user from the shell (for example: `atom app.js`), Atom crashes with an uncaught error `EEXIST: file already exists, mkdir '/usr/local/bin/atom'`. A picture of the full stacktrace is included below.

![Error Image](http://i.imgur.com/3qcihxe.png)

Atom works fine if launched any other way. It also works fine if launched from the shell as a root user. `atom -f` only outputs the error included in the picture above and nothing else. This problem persists between Atom installs and full removals of my local atom configuration. 

My guess is there's a misconfigured permission somewhere which is obviously specific to my system, and I'd love some help tracking it down. Thanks!

data.title: Precompile bootstrap
data.body:
Precompile the `static/bootstrap.less` file and ship a `static/bootstrap.css` instead.

This shaves ~10ms off of startup since the less import cache checks aren't run and the file system is only hit once for the `.css` file instead of 10 times for all the bootstrap imports.

data.title: Atom crashes after long usage on Ubuntu 15.04 (Vivid Beta)
data.body:
```
App load time: 372ms
[26608:0410/134123:INFO:renderer_main.cc(212)] Renderer process started
[26575:0410/134124:INFO:CONSOLE(388)] "Could not resolve 'project-palette-finder' to a package path", source: /opt/github/atom/share/atom/resources/app/src/package-manager.js (388)
[26575:0410/134124:INFO:CONSOLE(11)] "activate linter-jshint", source: /home/jordon/.atom/packages/linter-jshint/lib/init.coffee (11)
[26575:0410/134124:INFO:CONSOLE(11)] "activate linter-ruby", source: /home/jordon/.atom/packages/linter-ruby/lib/init.coffee (11)
[26575:0410/134125:INFO:CONSOLE(57)] "Window load time: 1425ms", source: file:///opt/github/atom/share/atom/resources/app/static/index.js (57)
X Error of failed request:  BadWindow (invalid Window parameter)
  Major opcode of failed request:  18 (X_ChangeProperty)
  Resource id in failed request:  0x2e001eb
  Serial number of failed request:  89
  Current serial number in output stream:  152
```

It should be noted that this does use node-gyp,node,npm provided by Ubuntu in a Docker image but we have the same crash without the Docker image on an isolated system.  

```
jordon@laptop:~/development/envygeeks/dockerfiles$  npm --version # => 1.4.21
jordon@laptop:~/development/envygeeks/dockerfiles$ node --version # => v0.10.25
```

data.title: Search with a new thing should clear the replace box
data.body: I search for something and the old replace value is still there making it confusing and harder to search. The replace box should get cleared out or have an option to specify that.

data.title: Mini editor keybindings don't match native text input keybindings
data.body:
In particular in a native text field (OS X anyway) I can use Up/Down to move or select to the start/end of my text field. These keybindings/commands ARE properly implemented in the standard TextEditor, it just looks like they've been intentionally left out of the mini editor. In particular if you look in `text-editor-element.coffee` you'll see:

```
atom.commands.add 'atom-text-editor:not([mini])', stopEventPropagation(
  'core:move-up': -> @moveUp()
  'core:move-down': -> @moveDown()
  'core:move-to-top': -> @moveToTop()
  'core:move-to-bottom': -> @moveToBottom()
...
```

I think the following commands should be included in the mini editor to match native behavior:

```
  'core:move-up': -> @moveUp()
  'core:move-down': -> @moveDown()
  'core:move-to-top': -> @moveToTop()
  'core:move-to-bottom': -> @moveToBottom()
  'core:select-up': -> @selectUp()
  'core:select-down': -> @selectDown()
  'core:select-to-top': -> @selectToTop()
  'core:select-to-bottom': -> @selectToBottom()
```

Does this seem like a reasonable change? If so I can make a pull request, just asking first since these seem to have been explicitly disabled in the mini editor.

data.title: Crash on Paste in Ubuntu
data.body:
I have a small project open and, if I paste from an external source (browser, etc), it will crash Atom and will have start a new Atom process. 

I'm on `v.0.189.0`

Let me know if you need any more detailed information if you cannot replicate it.

data.title: "Double click selection" should stick to the "variable name" pattern
data.body:
My main issue is with the character "$", currently when trying to select $myVar the double click only select myVar.
This is uber annoying since i'm used to call my variable like this.

Moreover when editing php scripts it gets more difficult to avoid this issue.

Overall, the double click selection should stick to the variable name pattern of the current language if possible, or accept the $ in the word, at least.
